diagrams.description: Aerospace engineering's origins trace to 1903 with the Wright Brothers' first powered flight at Kitty Hawk, establishing heavier-than-air flight principles. World War I (1914-1918) accelerated aircraft development for military purposes. The 1920s-30s brought commercial aviation expansion, metal aircraft construction, and jet engine concept development (Frank Whittle 1930, Hans von Ohain 1936). World War II (1939-1945) saw rapid advances with the first operational jet aircraft and V-2 rockets. The 1950s introduced supersonic flight (Chuck Yeager broke the sound barrier in 1947) and the beginning of the Space Age with Sputnik (1957). The 1960s witnessed the Apollo program leading to the moon landing (1969) and commercial jet age expansion. The 1970s-80s brought wide-body aircraft, Space Shuttle development, and composite materials adoption. The 1990s-2000s saw stealth technology, GPS integration, and International Space Station construction. The 2010s-2020s continue with reusable rockets (SpaceX), commercial spaceflight, electric aircraft development, hypersonic vehicles, and autonomous flight systems becoming reality.
diagrams.mermaid_code:
timeline
    title The History of Aerospace Engineering
    section The Dawn of Flight
        1903 : Wright Brothers - First powered flight
        1927 : Charles Lindbergh - First solo transatlantic flight
    section The Jet Age
        1939 : The Heinkel He 178, the first jet aircraft
        1947 : Chuck Yeager breaks the sound barrier
        1952 : The de Havilland Comet, the first commercial jet airliner
    section The Space Race
        1957 : Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite
        1961 : Yuri Gagarin, the first human in space
        1969 : Apollo 11, the first humans on the Moon
    section The Shuttle Era and Beyond
        1981 : The first Space Shuttle launch
        1998 : The International Space Station (ISS) begins construction
    section The 21st Century: The New Space Age
        2000s : Rise of private spaceflight (e.g., SpaceX, Blue Origin)
        2010s : Advancements in reusable rockets and CubeSats
